The position oi Baeon mid-way, as it were, between Scholasticism, on one side, and Modern Philosophy and Science, on the other, is so interesting that I cannot but think that much has even still to be learnt srom the study os his works, and especially os this, the chies and most influential of them all. Not only is the Novum Organum a collection of fine sayings and suggestive remarks, but a knowledge of it is indispensable to the student os the History either oi Logic, os Philosophy, or os the Physical Sciences. Moreover, it furnishes an excellent starting-point in the history os any of these subjects, whether we wish to go backwards or lorwards. But this very fact renders it essential that it should be accompanied with a copious commentary‚ both to point out the objects of interest, and to institute comparisons with what the reader has seen or will see elsewhere.
